text.tspan: [p is an attacker's success probability against
If you have the read cap (of size r+s bits),
you can find the storage index S, and use it
to get the current file contents Plain_R
(along with the other objects that are
stored on the server). This gives you r bits of
confidentiality, i.e. you know that it would take
approximately p.2^r / m work for someone
who doesn't have any of the orange secret
values to learn anything about the contents,
provided that either the convergence secret
CS is unknown or the file contents have
sufficient entropy. This also gives s/2 bits of
collision resistance, i.e. you know that it would
anyone, even the original uploader, to generate
a collision. It would take p.2^s / m work for
anyone other than the uploader to break
The integrity properties for read cap holders
are for the ciphertext, i.e. an incorrect cipher
integrity check. The ciphertext integrity can be
verified incrementally as the ciphertext is
If you have a verify cap (of size s bits), you
can verify that a given server has stored
sufficient information to allow reading the
caps are not supported.) It would take
about p.2^s / m work for anyone except the
original uploader of the file to forge a share
that incorrectly passes the verify check. The
index cap can be derived off-line from the
